report_title: Card Reward Program Services in the US
executive_summary: Macroeconomic improvements and greater acceptance of reward programs have driven growth for card reward program services. Over the past five years, consumers' willingness to accrue higher levels of debt led to increased demand for operators' complementary services. In addition, consumers have maintained a taste for rewards program services, while both national and local retailers have increased their card-linked marketing efforts. Nonetheless, robust economic volatility during COVID-19, coupled with rising interest rates, have harmed consumers' ability to manage large amounts of credit card debt, causing revenue to shrink at a CAGR of 0.3% to an estimated $836.9 million through the end of 2023, with an estimated 1.6% boost in 2023 alone. The push to hike interest rates accelerated credit card interest rates, which also negatively influenced operators' profit. In 2023, profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 17.5% of revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatility During Covid-19 Significantly Dampened Reward Program Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Card reward program services are highly dependent on steady economic conditions and higher credit card usage among consumers to ensure program interest remains high. During COVID-19, consumers significantly cut back their spending on discretionary activities in light of pandemic-era restrictions, with most spending focused on at-home items and mandatory purchases that were aided by a boost in disposable income levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wide Usage of Card Rewards Offsets Larger Losses
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although broader economic volatility significantly dampened operators' core revenue streams, the prevalence of card reward programs across different niches of the economy ensured steady demand from consumers. Many of the loyalty programs and rewards offered to consumers were geared toward leisure activities, such as travel, dining and social outings, which created a robust demand niche for operators that was disrupted during COVID-19 but shifted toward other modes of spending, such as online delivery services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Uncertainty Surrounding Regulatory Oversight Limited Growth Opportunities for Operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With no federal oversight surrounding credit card reward disclosures, operators continue to face uncertainty over future regulatory actions, while a segment of customers continue to have questions over how the reward programs operate.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Full Economic Recovery Will Bolster Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The continuation of economic recovery following COVID-19, coupled with favorable developments in core macroeconomic variables, will benefit operators and ensure a steady growth stream in demand for card reward services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continued Growth Of Bank Competition Will Curtail Larger Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although card reward program servicers are expected to benefit from booming economic conditions, the ease and popularity of credit cards as a financial tool ensures competition from larger banks and credit card issuers will continue to siphon customers away from operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Acceleration of Technology Will Create New Opportunities for Operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As technological advances continue to influence credit cards' security and ease of usage, operators can leverage technological development to enhance security and create easier access for customers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue within the travel sector, with core clients including airlines and hotels. A variety of businesses within the travel sector continue to garner interest among downstream customers, as their provision of rewards to cover the costs of airline fares and hotel stays incentivizes a variety of customers. Although the travel market underwent significant volatility during COVID-19, the rapid economic recovery and reopening of hotels for leisure activities helped boost demand among customers for travel-oriented card reward programs and services.

This market segment generates revenue via consumer-oriented sectors. Consumer brands often target customers via large retail stores like Target, as this is a frequent area of shopping for consumers within downstream markets. By establishing in-store rewards that can be accessed with a consumer's regular credit card, consumers can be incentivized to spend capital more frequently within these types of stores. Consistent growth in aggregate household debt continues to fuel a growing market for operators, as more customers make the switch to credit cards for their daily shopping needs.

This market segment generates revenue via the financial sector. Although major banks with significant capital have the tools to set up reward program services in-house, smaller banks, such as community banks and credit unions, often lack the financial muscle to do this, creating a unique demand niche for operators. As consumers continue to shift their spending habits toward credit cards, financial institutions from localized areas will continue to demand operators' services.

This market segment generates revenue from alternative sectors of the economy, such as gaming operators. Some entertainment venues, such as casinos, implement their own reward programs due to the inability of major credit cards to allow customers to gain rewards when playing at a casino. The stagnation in leisure time following economic reopening post-pandemic siphoned demand away from this market niche.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue via bank reward solution services, which enables operators to source different merchant offers and link them with bank debit and credit cards.

This product segment generates revenue via loyalty program services. Loyalty programs target specific customer niches and aim to leverage high credit card usage, with the programs popular among business cardholders and elite members that have higher credit card usage.
This product segment generates revenue via card reward program marketing services, which includes comprehensive marketing support for card reward programs via online and email marketing campaigns.
This product segment generates revenue from other services, which include implementation services, technical maintenance, offer management, consumer marketing and client services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for card reward program services is influenced by prevailing macroeconomic conditions. These include consumers' propensity to take on debt, the acceptance of card-linked offers and trends with respect to internal reward programs. Operators have benefited from households having increased their debt levels from $13.9 trillion in 2017 to an estimated $15.8 trillion in 2023. Aggregate card use has increased as domestic consumers have gained financial strength, to the benefit of operators.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Competition from credit card issuers and banks
demand_determinants.determinant_description: However, operators endure a massive amount of competition from credit card issuers and banks that develop and maintain internal card reward programs. Credit card issuers and depository institutions are massive in size, indicating that they have the capital to invest in their own card reward programs and tempering the need for operators. Given their scale, credit card issuers and commercial banks also have strong online presences and distribution capabilities, including access to numerous interactive marketing channels. This causes demand for card reward program service providers to be hampered by the presence of these massive, often self-sufficient institutions.

Demand declined in 2020 due to the spread of COVID-19. Issuance of new cards became a risky investment as consumer spending fell and the unemployment rate increased. During the pandemic, providing new programs were not beneficial to the company and customer as the customer was not willing to pay extra during periods of economic challenges.

business_locations.location_description: Card reward program servicers favor regions that have large populations, with the Southeast housing a significant chunk of the population in the United States. In states like Florida, the prevalence of metropolitan centers creates a diversified customer base for operators to sell their reward program services.

The Mid-Atlantic region benefits from a highly saturated population and is home to a variety of core financial services, such as banks and financial service companies. In states like New York, the prevalence of multiple financial headquarters, coupled with a booming population presence, enhances establishment demand.

Although the Southwest has far less population saturation compared with other regions, it has benefited from localized demand growth via booming suburban environments. In states like Texas, growing suburbs provide operators with a larger array of customers that have higher fiscal flexibility, which enables them to use credit cards at a higher frequency.
The Western regions exhibits many similarities with the Mid-Atlantic, as both regions have large populations and house many financial giants.

Some of the other regions with significantly lower establishment presence include the Great Lakes, the New England, the Plains and the Rocky Mountains regions. These regions lack large metropolitan centers and have far less usage of credit cards in the regions, which dampens demand for operators' services.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act targeted banks, card issuers and card network operators with additional regulation focusing on enforcing consumer rights and increasing security surrounding financial information.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure (CARD) Act of 2009
regulations_points.regulation_description: The CARD Act bans unfair rate increases, holds credit card companies accountable and standardizes credit card practices for young adults.

The proposed Credit Card Competition Act aims to lower the fees that merchants pay to credit card companies following each transaction, which could lead credit card companies to reduce rewards programs.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
There is no industry assistance, which is steady.
There is a high level of technology change.

factors_decreased_barrier.factor: Globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators compete internally on price, merchant network size, customer service, marketing tools and online site efficiency.
Operators face massive external competition from credit card issuers and banks that have their own card reward programs.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Diversified demand for reward programs across markets and consumer niches lowers market concentration.
High regulatory compliance costs limit growth opportunities, keeping operators localized and lowering concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest expenditure for operators continues to be wage costs, with card reward program servicers consistently relying on qualified, well-versed staff to service customers and manage network software systems.

Many of the additional costs accrued by operators are geared toward effective functioning of their system, with costs including external professional fees, insurance, travel and administrative expenses.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low capital investment relative to wages
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages in 2023, operators will allocate $0.02 in capital investment. In 2018, operators also spent $0.02 on capital investment for every $1.00 they spent on wages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital investments vary by operator size
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity in the industry varies primarily on the basis of the operator's size. Each operator relies on a talented and diverse team of employees for each of their service offerings.
The largest operators have also invested heavily in capital improvements like internet and mobile applications, analytic technologies, and regulatory compliance systems.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Card reward program services endured significant volatility during COVID-19, as customers changed shopping habits and cut back on leisure activities, dampening demand for card rewards.
Spiking interest rates to combat inflation significantly ate into consumers' purchasing power, influencing larger changes in revenue for operators.
Consistent growth in aggregate household debt across the US, with consumers shifting to credit cards as a form of payment, has stabilized core revenue channels for operators.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry relies heavily on technologies that support online marketing activities, such as websites, data management software, network management systems, and hardware and software to increase traffic, target consumers and improve user experience.
Technological advancements in web design are improving the quality of the user experience by enabling operators to display higher-quality images and offer interactive services.
Operators rely on computer technology to enhance security systems that ensure consumer data is safe, such as meeting Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards.
Large players like Cartera are investing in internet and mobile applications to ensure customers can make purchases and earn rewards from any location.
Operators are developing analytic technologies to more accurately determine the habits of their customers.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Card reward providers emphasize their value to clients by pinpointing their target audience and tailoring reward programs to their likings.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Growing business conducted online has led more consumers to use credit cards to make payments, presenting a larger opportunity for card reward providers to make programs for consumers.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are your establishments more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: The response to the financial crisis, the FDIC increased the amount to help maintain public confidence. Currently, all commercial deposits in a bank up to $250,000 are secured.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough capital reserved to be able to invest in new technology/software as soon as it becomes available?
FAQs.answer: Card reward providers generally are well-capitalized enough to make capital purchases necessary when technology changes.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins, in general, vary amongst card reward providers based on the companies they provide reward programs for.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Given the mounting demand for convenience, operators must take advantage of technological developments in the online and mobile spaces to generate and retain clients.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you by a satisfied client?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be able to secure reward offerings from a range of companies and geographical locations to expand their user bases.

FAQs.question: How do you hire workers? What is the training process for new hires like?
FAQs.answer: To continue operating, operators must maintain an experienced and highly talented workforce. This staff includes customer care representatives, engineers and data analysts, among other roles.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor your competition?
FAQs.answer: Operators contend with a growing level of external competition from credit card issuers and banks that develop and manage their own card reward programs and ancillary services. External competition for this industry is expected to continue rising in 2023.

FAQs.question: How does your company plan to react to this income range's increased saturation?
FAQs.answer: Wealthier individuals tend to spend more on their credit cards and more fervently demand rewards for this spending, to the benefit of operators. The market for consumers in this income range is expected to become increasingly saturated.

FAQs.question: What methods does your company use to capitalize on periods of increased aggregate household debt?
FAQs.answer: Aggregate household debt represents all outstanding credit market debt held by consumers, including credit card debt. Given the reliance of card-linked marketing on credit card issuers, an increasing amount of credit card debt tends to coincide with rising demand.
